byline.original: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times

headline.main: EVERY SOUL ON BOARD LOST.; THE CANADIAN SCHOONER MAGELLAN FOUNDERED IN LAKE MICHIGAN.
Wreck of the Ship John Milton on Moutauk Point, Long Island, and ALL Hands Lost--Eight Dead Bodies Found.

docs.snippet: The brig Jerome Knight, Capt. HIRAM PERKINS, was wrecked on the 23d ult. off the coast of North Carolina. The vessel belongs to Messrs. WHITON, BROWN  WHEELRIGHT, in Boston, and had left Wilmington, N.C., loaded with lumber for Marseilles and a ma...
docs.lead_paragraph: The brig Jerome Knight, Capt. HIRAM PERKINS, was wrecked on the 23d ult. off the coast of North Carolina. The vessel belongs to Messrs. WHITON, BROWN WHEELRIGHT, in Boston, and had left Wilmington, N.C., loaded with lumber for Marseilles and a market. She was a staunch-built vessel, only a year and a half old, and already rode out two or three violent gales.

headline.main: LOSS OF THE BRIG JEROME KNIGHT.; Eleven Persons Five on Wreck--The Captain's Wife and Infant Child among the number--Another Thrilling Story of Suffering at Sen.

docs.snippet: The public anxiety in relation to the fate of the tral America and her passengers, is at length [ally relieved by an announcement that the worst that was feared was nearest to the truth. Central America FOUNDERED ON THE 12th and only SIXTY OF A LI...
docs.lead_paragraph: The public anxiety in relation to the fate of the tral America and her passengers, is at length [ally relieved by an announcement that the worst that was feared was nearest to the truth. Central America FOUNDERED ON THE 12th and only SIXTY OF A LIST OF FIVE HUNDRED TWENTY-FIVE PASSENGERS, AND HER OFFICERS CREW, HAVE EEN SAVED.

headline.main: CENTRAL AMERICA FOUNDERED.; Six Hundred and Twenty-Six Persons on Board. Five Hundred and Sixty-Six Lives Lost. ONLY SIXTY SAVED. Forty Picked Up by the Norwegian Bark Eloise. TWENTY SAVED BY OTHER MEANS. Correct List of her Officers and Crew. STEAMERS SENT TO SEARCH FOR HER. DETAILS OF OTHER DISASTERS. Statements of the Commander of the Falcon, Empire City and Atlanta. Loss of the Steamship Norfolk. The U.S. Mail Steamship Columbia in the Storm. Loss of the Steamship Norfolk. From Key West. Arrival of the Steamship Joseph Whitney in Boston--The Loss of the Norfolk, & c. Arrival of the Alabama at Savannah--Th Schooner Ida Picked Up.
Wreck of the Schooner D. C. Foster--Three Men Drowned.

docs.snippet: From the Cleveland Herald. The bark Empire, of 350 tons, was wrecked on Marblehead Point, about four miles from the port of Sandusky. Eleven lives were lost, all on board except Captain MILLIGAN and a seaman. The Empire was bound from Toledo to To...
docs.lead_paragraph: From the Cleveland Herald. The bark Empire, of 350 tons, was wrecked on Marblehead Point, about four miles from the port of Sandusky. Eleven lives were lost, all on board except Captain MILLIGAN and a seaman. The Empire was bound from Toledo to Tonawanda, with a cargo of limber, shipped by J. W. RUSSELL, and consigned to ALEXANDER KENT.

headline.main: Wreck and Loss of Life on Lake Erie.

docs.snippet: Another of the terrible marine disasters which have made the name of Chicago dreadful in the oars of all sailors, occurred before this city yesterday. All day, and a good part of the previous night, a furious gate blew from the northeast, bringing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Another of the terrible marine disasters which have made the name of Chicago dreadful in the oars of all sailors, occurred before this city yesterday. All day, and a good part of the previous night, a furious gate blew from the northeast, bringing all the lake craft which happened to be this aide of Milwaukee to this port for safety.

headline.main: Torrible Ship wrecss on Lake Michigan.; VESSELS WRECKED--MANY LIVES LOST.

docs.snippet: A fleet of vessels lies in Hampton Roads-some ashore-some frozen fast in the ice. Lack of fuel and provisions has caused much distress to the crews and passengers on board them. Among the fleet is the fine ship Samuel Russell belonging to A. A. Lo...
docs.abstract: Jas. Adger sent to relieve vessels at Hampton Rds
docs.lead_paragraph: A fleet of vessels lies in Hampton Roads-some ashore-some frozen fast in the ice. Lack of fuel and provisions has caused much distress to the crews and passengers on board them. Among the fleet is the fine ship Samuel Russell belonging to A. A. Low BROTHER. She reached the Roads after a passage of six months from Loo Chow Foo, short of men and provisions.

headline.main: MORE WRECKS.; Twenty-four Vessels Ashore or IceBound in Hampton Roads, Va. THE JAMES ADGER SENT TO THEIR RELIEF. A FLEET IN DISTRESS.
